ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the ways religion and the body interact over various traditions.
I learned about the various ways in which physicality interacts with religion.
We touched on many different religions which I greatly appreciated
I learned how to engage with primary sources across religious traditions and developed the skills to analyze them in a scholarly context.
reading and analyzing skills, group participation

I gained many new insights into scholarly articles about the positionality of the body in religious studies. It was especially interesting to learn more about religious traditions I didn't know about beforehand, such as the Jain practice of Sallekhana. I enjoyed the way the class was structured around a major topic each week (such as health & illness, gender, transhumanism, etc...)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very good. I have no recommendations as to changing it.

Strengths: Prof Doerfler. Incredible lecturer and has natural propensity to lead the course. Covered broad and diverse content. Also appreciated the Perusal style and grade breakdown. 
Weaknesses: none
Strengths: interesting reading with a great professor

I particularly enjoyed how each week had its own topic and built on the methodologies introduced in prior courses. Perhaps this is a bit difficult to execute, but I would have liked a bit more explicit instruction on how to write a paper in religious studies. What are the norms and conventions, what makes a paper a "good" paper? I suppose we'll find out at the end of the week when grades come in?
possibly less weekly assignments, enjoyed the readings
This course is very well-organized and Prof. Doerfler's expectations are clear. She's very supportive and approachable and wants the best for everyone!
I thought the course was great, I just wish I had more time to do the readings. Professor Doerfler really does a good job of trying to stimulate good discussion.

I think this class was very strong, but I know it focuses on a different topic each semester and is taught by various faculty. As a non-religious studies major, I found each week's readings and discussions to be enthralling and engaging. Professor Doerfler also brought several faculty from the religious studies department & the divinity school to our weekly sessions, and it was interesting to learn about the work being done in these areas firsthand!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to a student who is interested in the body and religion. I did not choose this course out of interest but rather out of requirement.
Absolutely. You will learn so much, as a RLST major or not.
Yes I loved this class
Definitely a great class that is truly more than just a requirement.
yes, have a chance to learn from people with many different interests in religion
Absolutely! You learn so much about such interesting topics, and Prof. Doerfler is an expert!!

I would not if its not required only because religion and bodies isnt the most interesting topic in religious studies for me, that being said Professor Doerfler is a great Professor and the course will be great for you if you like the topic.
yes!
I would highly recommend this course as a non-religious studies major to anyone interested in the seminar's topic that year!
